comments.commentBody:
While happy in many ways, I wouldn't go overboard in praising the current, or any other, US administration here. There was simply a strategic opening for this deft move, in which normalization of relations will eventually negate the proxy legacy of Cuba, long a bothersome and tedious thorn in US foreign policy.

I am sure the Castro brothers' former patron will really feel tall in that saddle, when he sees pictures of US Marines enjoying shore leave in Havana within a year or so.

But really, this was quite a diplomatic coup from this administration, projecting both strength and conciliation.

The (accidental) neologism "hypocrat" and its cognate "hypocracy" (rule by uncontrollable liars) are a great idea. We need something to describe the Republican Congress. I nominate "hypocracy".

Tom
Most American TV is terrible!

comments.userLocation: Lost in the wilds of Maryland
comments.commentBody:
How do oppressive, dictatorial regimes control people in their nations? By limiting access to ideas and information.

Television, a much hated thing among the better educated (elites) in our country, brings ideas and information to oppressed people in the form of showing others in the world who have better clothing, drive their own cars, live in nice apartments, eat whatever they please and have time enough to argue about very silly, unimportant matters. Right now, television from the outside world is BANNED in Cuba. As the artificial, invisible walls fall between Cuba and America, expect to see a sea of satellite antennas in Havana pointed skyward over the coming months and years. Somehow, once dishes are no longer outlawed, Cubans will find a way to get subscriptions to American programs in both Spanish and English.

Marco Rubio is a relatively young man for a US Senator. He will likely live long enough to see his predictions about the future of Cuba turned into a mockery, a symbol of gross ignorance.

Cuba will find its way to greater freedom and more expansive individual rights by associating with the world at large (us) and adopting those elements that make sense to them. The Cuban dictatorship will find itself powerless to resist. The walls will tumble down. A people awakened will not be put back to sleep, not easily, in any case.

How many more yrs. was the embargo supposed to go? Another 50? 500 yrs.? I suppose so, since ignorance knows no limits.

Doug Terry
Thank you LuAnne for your contribution to a clean and unpolluted environment! What price can you place on pure water, clean air, and unspoiled land? Keep fighting the good fight!

I feel as if I've been through a workout... and it didn't help that I got started an hour late (technical problems loading the file). JALOPIES was the last word entered. That NW corner was tough. Oh, *that* kind of football. I was thinking Peter King, football writer (NFL-style football). PELE is so close to PEtE, too, spelling-wise.

Strangely, I had the other four theme entries correct without even knowing the reveal, just by recognizing them as (neat) words or phrases.

Most enjoyable puzzle in a while. Crunchy _and_ tasty. Plus SNOG!
Thanks, Timothy!

Frumkin - yes. no need to follow a misguided example. Germany has also sworn off nuclear energy. Instead they buy a good deal of it from France which makes 70% of its energy export from.....you guessed it, nuclear plants :-).
Romney isn't scary?
My general sense is that Jeb is neither scary nor demonstrably stupid, which puts him ahead of other nominees, Romney excepted.

"a President who's not above using lawless measures"

You really don't know your executive history, do you? Obama has never done anything other presidents didn't do in spades. He's practically an old-school conservative. Yet its Obama that gets vilified for everything previous presidents have done? Ever heard of Nixon going to China? During the height of the Cold War? In secret? He'd probably be impeached by today's Congress. No good deed goes unpunished, I guess.

As CraigM of Texas said, we deal with dictatorships on a regular basis.  Our bi-partisan "head in the sand" approach to communist China precludes anyone in America from feigning genuine dismay over opening relations with Cuba.
Aw, it makes me feel tempted to step back and rework history from 2000 again.
so can I make a deposit on a few adjoining cells in what will no doubt become Guantanamo Bay Beach Resort ?

I agree with Bittman's positions on the issues, but sadly don't agree that his remedy, a 'call to arms' to the populace has merit. Every advocate like Bittman claims they are promoting the populace's interests. As if the populace is just waiting for the OK from Bittman to bring reforms by overturning business as usual.
I believe Bittman's vision of the American public isn't accurate. He decries the corruption of Government but sees it as the outlier. I see Government corruption as merely a reflection of society's corruption. We have become a nation that worships materialism, consumption, ease, and affluence. Yes, effort and work are admired, but only as a means to those ends.

In all nations, what unites people to share burdens and benefits are great causes or unique cultural identity. Those have been lost in the US as globalization has replaced national identity and outsourcing waging war to 'volunteer' mercenaries and foreign surrogates has eliminated great causes. And multiculturalism(a positive for social harmony) has embittered traditionalist determiners of American ethos who have lost their social primacy.

What remains is a common striving for affluence, always an American aspiration. But technology has extended 'winner take all' economics to almost every aspect of commerce. Affluence will simply no longer be widely distributed. Bittman's appeal to the populace is in vain because the populace is grasping for the very corruptions he would reform.
Thank you, apohis. Well spoken, though few will understand.
Oh please.  The Cuban people are embargoed even from food.  You would have this continue?

Now multinational corporations can buy Cuban resources, land, water, housing, and medical facilities, and life will become even harder for the majority. While sellers of baubles and luxuries dazzle the poor, watch prices of rent go up, medical care become privatized and unavailable. Back to the good ol' Batista days when people lived like dogs and Havana was a private brothel for the rich of Miami. Basic medical care for the poor is more available for the poor in Cuba than in the US; life expectancy in Cuba is
slightly higher than in the US.
Free trade always enriches the elite and hurts the majority, ever since the
heyday of the slave trade.
Who cares? Menendez and his ilk know the tide of history is about to wash over them.

Thank you President Obama, for steps in the direction of normalization. Let us remove the barriers between peoples and nations. Let the people of the world travel and trade with each other! Cuba has done good things (excellent education and healthcare) along with bad (repress dissent). Open heart surgery that costs us 50,000 costs 500 there. Maybe we could both learn things from each other.
Nope.  Please explain . . . .
The graph does not show population.  It shows the unemployment rate.  Retirees are not counting in the Unemployment Rate as it is based on people who are actively looking for work

Kevin,
What am I missing : if more people are retiring then does that not mean that less people could be looking for work, thus driving down unemployment?

How much of the surging population was elderly people leaving the workforce - New York City retirees?  That may be one reason why the unemployment rate was so low with high population growth.  Not saying that it discredits any claims.  Also, how do we not know the housing bubble was due to demographic issues baby boomers retiring?

The Scandinavian countries also do not serve as policeman to the world. Their defense budget is minuscule compared to ours. If we had a true United Nations that shared military might, we Americans would be able to have a higher standard of living in terms of what counts...livable communities, universal health care, a decent infrastructure including public transportation, good educational opportunities for all, living wages, adequate time off, etc. With an adequate safety net, we might just feel more connected to our fellow Americans. The dog eat dog mentality prevails too often.

The political dynamics will change completely when oil turns around and gets pricier. The economic instability this will create will open the door for left and right wing candidates to become viable. Look at the timing for the price of oil to determine if a Warren candidacy is viable.

As always, it is great upheaval that creates larger than life leaders.

The medical care is good, and when multinational corporations start selling it,
Cuban citizens will be out of luck.
An end to the Cold War in the Americas is long overdue.
I travel a lot, and I assure you I won't set foot in the place until the castros are dead and/or there are solid shifts toward democracy.

While I think it makes sense to change our policy, the effect of hordes of American tourists will be blunted by the fact that Canadians and Europeans (and a lot of Americans) have been allowed to go there for years; I doubt there is much that new hordes of American tourists can show them that they already haven't seen.

And the last thing we need to do is go there to mock them. This sounds way too much like the stereotype of the ugly American tourist abroad. I also traveled within the East Bloc during my college years; I went there to learn, not to demonstrate some sense of superiority. What I found were other people, intrinsically no better or worse than myself, living in a bad system. When I go to Cuba sometime, I don't expect to find anything different.
What a great story. Focus, tenacity and the fierce determination of a born leader who knows to the depths of his soul the difference between right and wrong.
And who has behaved exactly that way since 2008, whatever it might be convenient for people who've never run for office or bargained for anything serious to believe.

In 2008 I had an opportunity to play basketball with President Obama back when basketball, not golf, was still his first passion. Though the president was no Michael Jordan, he was a smart player with a decent jump shot. But what impressed me most about the president's game was his willingness to do the dirty stuff--defend and rebound--as well as his tenacity--he didn't back down. I witnessed the president try to block a dunk attempt of a much younger, more athletic player and get knocked flat on his butt! Yet, the president got right back up and kept playing. The president also engaged in some good-natured trash talking, which told me that this guy could take it, as well as dish it out. After the games were over, I left the gym thinking this guy was going to be great for our country--he's a smart, gritty, thick-skinned guy who won't back down from a good fight. Fast forward to 2014. If I'm completely honest, I haven't seen much of THAT guy I played against in 2008. But in the last few weeks, I'm starting to see signs of that guy I was hoping to see in 2008. I'm not saying that Obama's executive order on immigration was the right thing to do or that reestablishing ties with Cuba is in our country’s best interest, but I do like THIS version of the President. A president who is willing to mix it up, stands up to Congress, and fights for the things he believes in. FINALLY! Although time is running low, Mr. President, if you keep this up, you can still hit a game winning shot!

Maybe ... Maybe not.

We'll never know, will we.

The profession of advocacy groups and leaders are no different that corporate types. They portray themselves as honest folk with positive objectives but are milking the monetary aspects and stray from honest presentation all the time.  Look at the head of Earthjustice and what he says about GMOs! It is appalling to the three federal agencies who monitor genetic engineering of crops and the environment for safety. Yet GMO medicines are great!

Our whole country is very corrupt, but we are unwilling to believe it.
We lie to ourselves and to everyone else.
We don't torture. We aren't racists. Our military prosecutes sex offenders to the fullest extent of the law. There is such thing as clean coal. There is a major war on coal. Fracking has no environmental risks.. Fish are plentiful in the ocean and regulation of fishing is a war on fishermen and their families. We never negotiate with terrorists. We never bow to pressure by terrorists. Cutting taxes on the rich stimulates the economy.
Oh yeah, um .. We are the good guys.

Good one, Robert, it reminds me of what you said at a San Francisco conference I attended about 8 years ago: "95% of Republican Congressmen are corrupt. For the Democrats, it's only 70%".

It's not just Blankenship and the judges he bribes. Fossil fuel companies are all gangster enterprises, with no regard for human life.

Our electoral system desperately needs an overhaul in order to slow their influence, to include full public financing of elections. Other countries actually do this. Prior efforts to effect incremental changes either contained loopholes or were reversed. The only way to succeed is to go all the way, and make a Congressman show his ideas and personality to the people directly- instead of being fed sound bites, and working with wardrobe consultants and photo op producers.

While we're at it, we could get television news producers to cooperate, especially when it comes to debate questions. Key issues such as global warming and free trade for Walmart junk from China are avoided, since policy changes might disturb a key corporate donor. Network moderators prefer to talk about culture wars and military strategy, without even questioning deadly pollution, invasion, and torture. They each want to be the most macho, while mouthing platitudes about "working American families" and "our enemies". Rule 1 in high school debate: define your terms. Our leaders never got that far.

You are one of the few who still tells truth to power, Robert. Show up more often.
